awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SPARC: Facilitating Research, Experimentation, and Education in Spatial Archaeometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC) program promotes the use of spatial analysis, 3D modeling, as well as satellite, aerial, and terrestrial remote sensing in archaeological research projects. The things archaeologists study—from artifacts to sites to landscapes—almost always have a spatial component and spatial analysis is therefore central to contemporary archaeological investigations. Today, the increasing availability and sophistication of geospatial technologies is not merely generating new data but is facilitating entirely novel means of engaging with the archaeological record and exploring the human past. However, the high costs of instrumentation and software, combined with the expertise they require, create hurdles for many archaeologists who aim to deploy geospatial technologies in research projects. SPARC 1) facilitates high-impact spatial archaeometric research, 2) advances emerging methodologies towards greater community use, 3) promotes this new knowledge across the discipline, and 4) promotes inclusion of junior and underrepresented scholars and institutions in leadership roles and in its training schema. Through its innovative approach to supporting collaborative archaeological research, the SPARC program makes costly geospatial technologies and specialized domain expertise available to researchers from a wide range of backgrounds, including early career scholars and those at minority serving institutions, enhancing diversity, equity, and inclusion within archaeological research. The program also provides education and training opportunities for students and professionals seeking to use geospatial techniques in their own research, broadening the impact of the program far beyond individual supported projects.

The SPARC program supports archaeological researchers seeking to integrate geospatial technologies and methods into their investigations by facilitating collaborations with research faculty and staff and the technological infrastructure from the University of Arkansas' Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies (CAST), Dartmouth College’s Spatial Archaeometry Lab (SPARCL), and the University of Arkansas’ MicroCT Imaging Consortium for Research and Outreach (MICRO). Researchers apply to the program through a competitive, peer-reviewed process, and successful proposals receive support from geospatial technologies experts in both field and lab settings, access to specialized equipment and software, and intensive training opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Spatial Archaeometry Research Collaborations (SPARC) Program, a multi-institutional initiative that works to expand access to and promote the use of geospatial technologies in archaeological research. Since 2013, the SPARC program has supported 47 research projects in 23 countries (and including 12 U.S. states), led by 97 PIs and Co-PIs from 63 different institutions, producing dozens of prominent publications, conference presentations, and online tools or data repositories, and has generated $2.47 million in new grant funding.  This report concerns the contributions of the University of Arkansas’ Center for Advanced Spatial Technologies (CAST).

Geospatial methods including aerial and satellite imaging, large-array terrestrial geophysics, multi-sensor drone-based mapping, MicroCT scanning, and 3D visualization are rapidly transforming how archaeologists discover, document, and interpret the human past. However, the high costs of instrumentation and software combined with the technical expertise these technologies require create significant hurdles for researchers, preventing their widespread integration into archaeological investigations, particularly for junior scholars or those at less well-resourced institutions. The SPARC program seeks to bridge these by making the equipment, software, and experienced staff at CAST as well as the Dartmouth College Spatial Archaeometry Lab (SPARCL) available to archaeological research projects through a competitive, peer-reviewed application process.  

Proposals to the SPARC program selected for in-kind awards collaborate with SPARC faculty and staff members in planning projects, undertaking field data collection, conducting lab-based analyses, and preparing results for presentation, publication, and sustainable archiving. SPARC also offers an array of online educational and training resources, sponsors in-person workshops and consultations at major conferences, and hosts scholars for residencies that enable intensive collaborative research and skills development.  

During the two-year project period dating 9/1/2021-8/31/2023, major activities at CAST included:  

  • Four new major research projects. Described in greater detail on the SPARC website (https://sparc.cast.uark.edu/about/funded), they represent advances in sUAS (drone) technologies and a dedication to open-access science. Projects focused on LiDAR collection of a 19th century convict leasing camp in Tennessee, coordination with a Native American community to document 20th century gathering spaces of the Wichita in Oklahoma, the mobilization of legacy data from a research project in Turkey, and the modeling of contemporary erosion and landform change to protect heritage sites. 

  • Three smaller-scale collaborations: consultation on data organization in the open-source geospatial platform QGIS; cleaning of a multi-billion point cloud dataset associated with a UNESCO site, for a successful grant-pitch of its open-access publication; and testing out new drone capabilities for rugged, remote fieldwork: these represent the substantive and wide-ranging contributions SPARC offers the community to problem-solve spatial data questions. 

Training opportunities and resources comprise part of SPARC activities. We published an open-access teaching resource on microCT applications for archaeology for university-level students, available on the SPARC GitHub repository. We also hosted a training workshop on drone-based sensors for archaeological applications at the 87th Annual Meeting of the Society for American Archaeology. 19 registrants from academic institutions, federal and state agencies, and industry took part. Lastly, a free, two-day photogrammetry workshop at the University of South Carolina allowed the direct transfer of knowledge about spatial archaeology to communities interested in public heritage. The workshop's 15 participants represented faculty, graduate students, and staff from the Departments of History and Anthropology, Libraries, University Museum, and SCIAA; local and state heritage practitioners including the Richmond County Library, DNR, and SHPO; and local CRM firms.    

2021 saw the establishment of the SPARC residency program, where individual researchers undertake a short period of intensive study, collaborative research, or project development. Researchers engage in short periods of supervised training on equipment or software, analysis, post-processing assessments of data, work on collaborative publications, and/or plan for future collaborations. Residencies provide a unique way to engage especially with graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and early career researchers on their projects, allowing for more personal and extended interaction    

These research activities resulted in a range of deliverables, including: 

  • Ten professional conference presentations at the 2022 and 2023 annual meetings of the Society for American Archaeology, the 2021 Biennial Meeting of the Society for Africanist Archaeology, and the 2022 Biennial Meeting of The Association of Southern African Professional Archaeologists; 

  • Two invited lectures: in the Hanberry Lecture in Historic Preservation at the University of Virginia, given by J. Cameron Monroe; and in Carla Klehm and Malcolm Williamson’s 2023 Keynote presentation for the Applications of Photogrammetry workshop at the University of South Carolina; 

  • Five publications, appearing in the peer-reviewed Journal of Field Archaeology, Advances in Archaeological Practice, Journal of Archaeological Science: Reports, and Archaeological Research in Asia. These were archived in NSF’s Public Access Repository.   

Through our research and its outcomes, we forward knowledge of the human past across many time periods and cultures. We enable researchers to achieve more, and more efficiently, the data by which these stories are composed, and help raise their visibility to a broader academic and public audiences.
